projects.title: Groundbreak
projects.description: What if the arena itself were your arsenal? Groundbreak is a roguelike tactics RPG where you sling elemental tiles to trigger reactions such as sandstorms and fireballs to escape a multi-floor dungeon. As part of a four-person team, I led combat design, building the tile-flinging mechanics, elemental reaction system, and enemy AI powered by A* pathfinding. The most rewarding part was playtesting with over ten players to balance the elements and create diverse, fun build paths. (RIP Sandstorm)

projects.title: Keystone
projects.description: What if NPCs were the puzzle pieces? Keystone is an open-world adventure where NPC behaviors intertwine. By herding, distracting, trading aggro, and luring enemies, players uncover hidden paths and secrets woven into the world’s ecosystem. Working in a four-person cross-functional team, I designed six dungeons centered on player-enemy interaction and built a choose-your-own-adventure prototype to test puzzle flow and ecosystem design early in development.

projects.title: Fakeflix
projects.description: FakeFlix was my first real dive into front-end development. I expanded a 35k+ React/Redux codebase to add a “Because You Watched” recommendations rail and build new reusable UI components. It was a crash course in how React and Redux intertwine to handle complex states and the satisfaction that comes with making interfaces feel as good as they look. I also dipped my toes in DevOps work for the first time, setting up GitHub Actions to automate testing and keep the codebase stable.

projects.title: Steam Recommendation Engine
projects.description: A peek behind Steam's discovery queue turned hands-on ML lab. I built a sequence-aware recommender with a SASRec Transformer and learned the habits that actually move the needle: evaluating on a store-like slate, keeping histories chronological, and the power of careful masking. From there, the fun was in the tinkering: swapping signals, rerunning vectorized scorers, and seeing the ranking shifts. Turns out raw counts can be problematic, but it's nothing normalization can't solve.

projects.title: Personal Website
projects.description: You’re on it! Designed in Figma and built with Next.js, React, and Tailwind CSS, it began as a way to challenge myself to grow in the field of front-end development. A passion project inspired by League of Legends’ champion pages, I wanted to create a site where every element not only looked good, but felt good. I focused on dealing with different aspect ratios, creating a hassle-free experience no matter what device you're viewing it from. Now, it's my hub for showcasing projects and the things I love the most.
